channel.title: BBC News - Asia

item.title: Yongbyon: UN says North Korea appears to restart nuclear reactor
item.description: A UN report says the reactor, which can produce plutonium for weapons, has been active since July.

item.title: Afghanistan: US investigating civilian deaths in Kabul strike
item.description: The strike aimed to stop a suicide bomber, but reportedly left nine Afghan civilians dead.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympic 2020: Avani Lekhara wins historic gold for India in shooting
item.description: Avani Lekhara has become the first Indian woman to win a Paralympics gold medal.

item.title: China bans exams for six-year-old school children
item.description: The education ministry says excessive exams are affecting the physical and mental health of pupils.

item.title: Covid: Australia records 1,000th death from the pandemic
item.description: The country has fared better than many nations but is seeing more infections than ever before.

item.title: Vietnam lockdown adds to global coffee supply concerns
item.description: Wholesale coffee prices have risen by 50% this year as supplies have been hit around the world.

item.title: New Zealand woman dies after receiving Pfizer vaccine
item.description: Officials say she also had other medical issues which could have contributed to her death.

item.title: Afghanistan: US drone strike 'eliminates airport bomb threat'
item.description: The strike on a vehicle prevented another suicide bombing by Islamic State, military officials say.

item.title: Bodies of US troops killed in Kabul returned to America
item.description: A "dignified transfer" ceremony takes place at Dover Air Force Base, Delaware, to receive their remains.

item.title: Afghanistan: UK sceptical of Taliban safe passage pledge, says minister
item.description: The government is seeking international support to ensure the militants allow people to leave Afghanistan.

item.title: Japan's huge army of under-employed ex-housewives
item.description: Why women are still battling for better jobs in the world's third largest economy.

item.title: Herat under the Taliban: residents on the new rulers
item.description: People in Afghanistanâ€™s third-largest city, Herat, explain how life has changed in recent weeks.

item.title: Afghanistan: British ambassador home as last UK troops leave
item.description: Sir Laurie Bristow arrives on one of the last flights carrying UK personnel back from Afghanistan.

item.title: Possum skin cloaks: Reviving an Aboriginal cultural tradition
item.description: Indigenous people in south-east Australia are reviving an expression of cultural identity.

item.title: Afghanistan: Black Hawks and Humvees - military kit now with the Taliban
item.description: As the insurgents swept through Afghanistan they inherited an arsenal of US-made equipment.

item.title: In India, growing clamour to criminalise rape within marriage
item.description: An Indian court ruled that forced sex with a spouse is not rape. Campaigners say it's time for new laws.

item.title: Afghan music school falls silent under Taliban rule
item.description: As the new regime bans music, the head of Afghanistan's national music school says students are scared.

item.title: Shein: China fashion giant investigates 'false' anti-Uyghur job ads
item.description: Shein said it did not fund or approve adverts that suggested some ethnic minorities need not apply.

item.title: Covid-19: The Indian children who have forgotten how to read and write
item.description: Schools in India have been closed for more than a year, with learning outcomes falling drastically.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: The lowdown on being disabled in Japan
item.description: From moon riders to job quotas, three residents give the lowdown on being disabled in Japan.

item.title: Afghanistan: Where will refugees go after Taliban takeover?
item.description: Thousands of people are scrambling to flee Afghanistan after the Taliban took control of the country.
